Users with the Basic access tier on entwickler.de have access to all READ content, which includes articles, but they do not have access to video formats such as recordings of sessions or tutorials. Recordings from live events, tutorials, or conference sessions are typically restricted to Fullstack or Elevate tiers or require separate add-on purchases. Therefore, a user with the Basic tier cannot watch recordings unless they purchase the relevant add-on or upgrade their membership [1.] .
In summary, Basic tier users can read articles but do not have access to session or tutorial recordings by default. To watch recordings, they would need to upgrade or buy add-on access.

'abstract': In a world of 5G (no conspiracy theories please!) smartphones, smart TVs and smart homes, we're inviting more tech into our lives than ever. We're sleepwalking into a future nobody asked for, but maybe many fear. How always-on Microphones, Cameras and AI are creating a 'digital panopticon' none of us probably want or need, unless you're Amazon. Should we become 'digital preppers'? Is the privacy and security risk so high, what are the stakes? This is an anthro-technologist view on how dumb an idea the smart revolution is and how we've eroded our social contracts in favour of big tech.

'abstract': Recently, concerns over the cost, complexity, and maintainability of serverless solutions seem to be growing. The ever-increasing number of available services and a growing ecosystem can further increase the confusion or perceived risk of going serverless. This talk will build on 7 years of experience building and maintaining serverless solutions to walk through the ground-up design of a brand-new serverless application. We’ll discuss common questions and concerns including data architecture, security, cost, and maintainability. The solution will be shown using a combination of system diagrams, as well as platform and code examples in Firebase and Google Cloud.

'abstract': Over the years we've seen a pattern across some of the use cases that customers have brought to us: they want to monitor the transactions that their business is actually responsible for -- financial trades, packages, calls, payments, etc., and they want their IT ops and engineering teams to start troubleshooting from that vantage point. Conventional wisdom for years has been that distributed tracing (and its predecessor, Application Performance Monitoring) is the right technology to solve these problems. We'll walk through why that might not be the case, and how we've been able to solve these use cases using log data.

'abstract': Explore the seamless integration of Puppeteer’s browser automation API with Cypress, a leading end-to-end testing framework, to amplify web testing capabilities. Puppeteer, renowned for its robust browser control toolkit, enhances Cypress by extending testing functionalities beyond its native scope. In this session, participants will learn how to integrate Puppeteer with Cypress for advanced testing scenarios, such as interacting with third-party services, web scraping, and handling file uploads. Discover optimization strategies to leverage Puppeteer within Cypress tests, improving test coverage and reliability. Practical examples will demonstrate the combined power of Puppeteer and Cypress, empowering attendees to elevate their web testing practices effectively.

'abstract': In the high-pressure world of DevOps, where speed, innovation, and reliability are paramount, one often overlooked factor can be the game-changer your team needs. Join us for a thought-provoking journey into the uncharted territory of the impact of psychological safety on DevOps. In this captivating conference talk, we will delve deep into the unexplored realm of psychological safety and how it can revolutionize your DevOps practices. Discover the untold stories of teams that thrived by fostering a culture of trust and openness, and learn how this secret weapon can lead to higher productivity, faster releases, and better collaboration. Get ready to be inspired, as we unveil the hidden forces that drive top-performing DevOps teams and reveal practical strategies to nurture psychological safety within your own organization. Don't miss this opportunity to gain a competitive edge and become a DevOps trailblazer! Join us and embark on a journey of transformation that will leave you wondering how you ever operated without it.

'title': Wearable, Shareable... Unbearable?

'abstract': In a world of 5G (no conspiracy theories please!) smartphones, smart TVs and smart homes, we're inviting more tech into our lives than ever. We're sleepwalking into a future nobody asked for, but maybe many fear. How always-on Microphones, Cameras and AI are creating a 'digital panopticon' none of us probably want or need, unless you're Amazon. Should we become 'digital preppers'? Is the privacy and security risk so high, what are the stakes? This is an anthro-technologist view on how dumb an idea the smart revolution is and how we've eroded our social contracts in favour of big tech.

'abstract': In a landscape dominated by skepticism and the pervasive 'zero-trust' mindset, developers and researchers in machine learning technology stand at the forefront, tasked with bridging the gap between insights and stakeholder confidence. By implementing methodologies that underscore transparency, rigor, and continual communication, these professionals adeptly navigate the complexities inherent in the zero-trust environment. As organizations endeavor to harmonize competing objectives of usability and security, the integration of research-driven insights assumes utmost importance. This presentation endeavors to arm participants with actionable strategies and pragmatic insights to excel in the intricate domain of zero-trust cybersecurity, promoting collaboration, and mutual understanding among developers, researchers, and stakeholders alike.

'abstract': 9 von 10 Webanwendungen haben Sicherheitslücken – und das schon seit Jahren. Es vergeht kaum eine Woche, ohne dass ein großer Sicherheitsvorfall bekannt wird. Mit weiter zunehmender Digitalisierung werden sowohl die Anzahl als auch der Schweregrad der erfolgreichen Angriffe steigen. Das muss besser werden! Aus diesem Grund werfen wir einen Blick auf den aktuellen Status Quo der Web Application Security. Welche Informationen und Tools rund um die Web-Sicherheit bietet das Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) dieses Jahr? Macht KI Anwendungen sicherer oder sind KI-Anwendungen unsicher? Und was kann das „Problem zwischen Stuhl und Tastatur“ tun – sind Passkeys ein Allheilsbringer oder birgt der Verzicht auf Passwörter auch Gefahren.

'title': Regaining choice, flexibility and control over your Metrics, Logs and Traces with Cribl
'parentName': DevOpsCon London 2025
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2025-05-14T08:30:00.000Z'
'abstract': Collecting, processing and storing telemetry has become expensive, static, and causes a loss of control over your observability approach. 'title': From GPU Burn‑Rate to Budget‑Friendly: Real‑World Hacks for SFTing Huge LLMs
'parentName': MLcon New York 2025
'language': 'EN'

'abstract': Supervised fine‑tuning (SFT) is still the gold‑standard for aligning large language models to niche domains, yet training bills can dwarf the project budget. This talk walks through the production SFT pipeline we built for LLM (7B → 470 B parameters) and shows how we cut per‑run cost by 42% while shortening wall‑clock time by 28%—all without model‑quality regressions. Attendees will see how we combined parameter‑efficient tricks (LoRA → QLoRA), 3‑D parallelism, FlashAttention‑3, mixed‑precision FP8, and AWS Trainium 2 clusters to squeeze every last TFLOP‑second. We’ll share concrete metrics, CLI snippets, and the open‑sourced orchestration package that glues it together. Expect a brutally honest discussion of what broke, how we fixed it, and where the next 10% of savings will come from

'abstract': Platform engineering promises so much, from developer productivity to better operational efficiency, and yet the Trough of Disillusionment still beckons. Touring a collection of real-world examples where platforms swim or sink through the lense of philosophy, Russ will explore the many choices you can make that will make the difference between a successful platform that your teams will love and a franken-platform that no one wants to touch. Together we'll explore which myths hold and which fold under scrutiny so that you have the best possible chance of building a loved internal developer platform. Why?  Because your developers are worth it(TM).

'abstract': In the dynamic landscape of DevOps, minimizing downtime is critical. In a perfect world, applications never fail, but the reality is that outages are inevitable. It remains imperative for IT departments to reduce both the frequency and duration of these disruptions. Despite the clear advantages, many organizations are reluctant to embrace automation due to entrenched manual processes and a lack of resources. In this session, we’ll explore how automation—when combined with real-time observability — can proactively prevent outages and accelerate recovery when incidents do occur. We’ll cover best practices and common challenges in building automation strategies that are both scalable and sustainable. Attendees will leave with actionable insights into how observability-driven automation can improve operational resilience and drive continuous improvement across the software delivery lifecycle.

'title': The Observability Reset: 4 Foundational Principles for O11y That Scales
'parentName': DevOpsCon New York 2025
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2025-09-30T08:15:00.000Z'
'abstract': Let’s face it, collecting metrics, logs, and traces isn’t enough anymore. Most o11y stacks today are drowning in telemetry, buried in cost overruns, and spread so thin across tools that they’ve become more noise than signal. The classic SaaS-based model is cracking. This talk lays out 4 foundational principles for building a sustainable observability posture that scale with infra and budget: - Bring Your Own Cloud (BYOC): SaaS o11y is financially unsustainable at scale. - Consolidate or Bust: DevEx suffers when visibility is fragmented- consolidation isn’t a luxury - it’s a requirement. - Standardize Everything: Open protocols, pluggable pipelines, and vendor-neutral APIs are the only way forward, or your o11y is a ticking liability. - Self-Reliance: You can’t rely on app-level instrumentation forever - eBPF enables scalable o11y without complexity This session pulls from real-world deployments and lessons learned helping engineering teams scale visibility without compromise.

'documentId': 'qK5avF5kpuXTM43dn'
'chunk_id': '687ad5f0eb1b160a4cabda48'
'access': 'restricted'

'contentType': 'RHEINGOLD'
'title': AI-powered learning recommendation system: a map and match approach
'parentName': ML Con Berlin 2022
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2022-11-29T15:45:00.000Z'
'abstract': Among the challenges faced by Human Resources (HR) professionals is the ability to match learning programs to career paths or to individual employees. At the core of this obstacle is the difference between the terms used to describe a training course and those used in the HR systems to describe jobs and career paths. Simply put, no standard terminology is used, either by the employees in the corporate system or by the learning industry professionals. To alleviate this problem, we have created a mapping & matching framework which allows to automatically connect learning with the other areas of corporate talent management. Our solution relies on a standardized database of 3,000 occupations and 13,000 skills. Mapping algorithms are built (i) to identify the occupations which best correspond to a user’s job title (present or desired) and (ii) to identify the skills referred to in a course description. Matching algorithms take the mapping results to estimate the similarity between every single course and user’s profile and provide the top courses that best match to a given user’s profile. The level of accuracy achievable at each step and their variation with some of the properties of the input parameters will be discussed.

'parentDescription':

'indexSeriesName': 'Berlin'
'author': 'Khieu Nguyen'

Matching algorithms take the mapping results to estimate the similarity between every single course and user’s profile and provide the top courses that best match to a given user’s profile. 'abstract': Are your websites accessible to all users? Are all the users able to interact with your application as intended regardless of their disabilities? Accessibility often remains an afterthought, even today. I'm here to share how we can change that. In this talk, we will explore best practices for building user interactions for websites that are accessible and user-friendly for our users. Using semantic HTML and ARIA attributes, we will cover strategies for interaction from a simple button to navigation, to different form elements and custom components. After this session, the audience will understand how users can use websites in different ways. They will learn different ways to test a scenario and see practical code solutions on how to make the interactions accessible.

'title': Welcome and Opening // Keynote: (Ab)User Experience: How the Dark Side of Product and Security Can Be Used for (Ab)User Stories, (Mis)Use Cases and Threat Modelling
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2023
'language': 'EN'

'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'title': Welcome and Opening // Keynote: (Ab)User Experience: How the Dark Side of Product and Security Can Be Used for (Ab)User Stories, (Mis)Use Cases and Threat Modelling
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2023
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2023-05-23T07:00:00.000Z'
'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'abstract': Improving your product and better understanding your users. That's the promise of tracking. Through a case study, we will present how at Instapro-group, we use tracking to improve our marketplace using Snowplow, an open-source event analytics platform. We will detail the different types of tracking implementations available, as well as how our infrastructure handles significant volume spikes with S3, and how we validate and enrich our data with Kinesis. However, the main focus will be on the adoption and valorization of this 'source of truth' among our teams and data engineers. We will explain how we created an event catalog and implemented a monitoring and alert system. Discover how we have leveraged this data to improve our global user experience.

'abstract': You wrote an API specification, documented your endpoints, and published SDKs. Here’s a question, though: Does your API actually solve your users’ problems? Providers often focus on features and underlying technologies of their APIs, while failing to address the use cases their API is used for – or their assumptions don't match the reality. Developers integrating the API are frustrated, spend extra time on integration analysis, or look for another provider. Let's take a closer look at API integrations from a developers' perspective. In this session, I will show how to discover, prioritize, and present use cases for your API, how to include use cases in API design, and how to empower users to solve their problems using your API more easily.

'title': Welcome and Opening // Keynote: (Ab)User Experience: How the Dark Side of Product and Security Can Be Used for (Ab)User Stories, (Mis)Use Cases and Threat Modelling
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2023
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2023-05-23T07:00:00.000Z'
'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'abstract': The tutorial is over, and already, the problems begin. How do I structure my components? What should the appropriate directory hierarchy look like? Do I need to worry about central state management?  In this workshop, we'll delve into these and other questions. Through practical examples that you'll work on yourself, you'll learn how to continuously modernize your components during development and actively work with the architecture of your application. You'll learn when to use custom hooks and when a simple helper function is sufficient. React focuses on creating user interfaces and leaves everything else up to you. As a result, a huge ecosystem has formed around the library.  In this workshop, you'll learn about some of the most popular libraries for React, how to generally integrate such extensions into your application, and what to watch out for.  Some of the libraries include react-i18next, react-query, or react-hook-form.

'abstract': Observability budgets are under pressure, downtime is costly, and operational errors can have real business impact. Adopting OpenTelemetry can help teams take control of telemetry data, streamline observability, and reduce incidents—but knowing where to start and what to expect can be challenging.In this session, we’ll holistically explore best practices from multiple OpenTelemetry deployments and their results, including: - Getting started: how to prioritize telemetry adoption and define key observability goals - Common challenges: pitfalls teams encounter and strategies to overcome them - Maximizing value: how to leverage telemetry effectively to detect issues early and accelerate recoveryAttendees will leave with actionable insights to proactively identify opportunities for adoption, reduce downtime, and make observability a true enabler of faster, proactive operations.

'title': AWS Free Tier: the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly

'abstract': In recent months many experts in the AWS community have been questioning the AWS Free Tier, advocating for sandbox accounts on AWS and hard billing limits that cannot be exceeded. What safety nets can you put in place as a developer and what are the most common mistakes to avoid unexpected bills when experimenting with new services with the AWS Free Tier?

'parentDescription':

'abstract': You wrote an API specification, documented your endpoints, and published SDKs. Here’s a question, though: Does your API actually solve your users’ problems? Providers often focus on features and underlying technologies of their APIs, while failing to address the use cases their API is used for – or their assumptions don't match the reality. Developers integrating the API are frustrated, spend extra time on integration analysis, or look for another provider. Let's take a closer look at API integrations from a developers' perspective. In this session, I will show how to discover, prioritize, and present use cases for your API, how to include use cases in API design, and how to empower users to solve their problems using your API more easily.

'abstract': The tutorial is over, and already, the problems begin. How do I structure my components? What should the appropriate directory hierarchy look like? 'title': Welcome and Opening // Keynote: (Ab)User Experience: How the Dark Side of Product and Security Can Be Used for (Ab)User Stories, (Mis)Use Cases and Threat Modelling
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2023
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2023-05-23T07:00:00.000Z'
'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'abstract': You wrote an API specification, documented your endpoints, and published SDKs. Here’s a question, though: Does your API actually solve your users’ problems? Providers often focus on features and underlying technologies of their APIs, while failing to address the use cases their API is used for – or their assumptions don't match the reality. Developers integrating the API are frustrated, spend extra time on integration analysis, or look for another provider. Let's take a closer look at API integrations from a developers' perspective. In this session, I will show how to discover, prioritize, and present use cases for your API, how to include use cases in API design, and how to empower users to solve their problems using your API more easily.

'abstract': You wrote an API specification, documented your endpoints, and published SDKs. Here’s a question, though: Does your API actually solve your users’ problems? Providers often focus on features and underlying technologies of their APIs, while failing to address the use cases their API is used for – or their assumptions don't match the reality. Developers integrating the API are frustrated, spend extra time on integration analysis, or look for another provider. Let's take a closer look at API integrations from a developers' perspective. In this session, I will show how to discover, prioritize, and present use cases for your API, how to include use cases in API design, and how to empower users to solve their problems using your API more easily.

'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'abstract': Improving your product and better understanding your users. That's the promise of tracking. Through a case study, we will present how at Instapro-group, we use tracking to improve our marketplace using Snowplow, an open-source event analytics platform. We will detail the different types of tracking implementations available, as well as how our infrastructure handles significant volume spikes with S3, and how we validate and enrich our data with Kinesis. However, the main focus will be on the adoption and valorization of this 'source of truth' among our teams and data engineers. We will explain how we created an event catalog and implemented a monitoring and alert system. Discover how we have leveraged this data to improve our global user experience.

'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'abstract': Are your websites accessible to all users? Are all the users able to interact with your application as intended regardless of their disabilities? Accessibility often remains an afterthought, even today. I'm here to share how we can change that. In this talk, we will explore best practices for building user interactions for websites that are accessible and user-friendly for our users. Using semantic HTML and ARIA attributes, we will cover strategies for interaction from a simple button to navigation, to different form elements and custom components. After this session, the audience will understand how users can use websites in different ways. They will learn different ways to test a scenario and see practical code solutions on how to make the interactions accessible.

'title': Why Your API Doesn’t Solve My Problem: Putting Use Cases First

'abstract': You wrote an API specification, documented your endpoints, and published SDKs. Here’s a question, though: Does your API actually solve your users’ problems? Providers often focus on features and underlying technologies of their APIs, while failing to address the use cases their API is used for – or their assumptions don't match the reality. Developers integrating the API are frustrated, spend extra time on integration analysis, or look for another provider. Let's take a closer look at API integrations from a developers' perspective. In this session, I will show how to discover, prioritize, and present use cases for your API, how to include use cases in API design, and how to empower users to solve their problems using your API more easily.

'title': Welcome and Opening // Keynote: (Ab)User Experience: How the Dark Side of Product and Security Can Be Used for (Ab)User Stories, (Mis)Use Cases and Threat Modelling
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2023
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2023-05-23T07:00:00.000Z'
'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'title': Making Interactions Accessible to All Users

'abstract': Are your websites accessible to all users? Are all the users able to interact with your application as intended regardless of their disabilities? Accessibility often remains an afterthought, even today. I'm here to share how we can change that. In this talk, we will explore best practices for building user interactions for websites that are accessible and user-friendly for our users. Using semantic HTML and ARIA attributes, we will cover strategies for interaction from a simple button to navigation, to different form elements and custom components. After this session, the audience will understand how users can use websites in different ways. They will learn different ways to test a scenario and see practical code solutions on how to make the interactions accessible.

'abstract': In a world of serverless architecture; how do developers convince their users that they and their code can be trusted? 'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'abstract': In a world of serverless architecture; how do developers convince their users that they and their code can be trusted? How can developers convince their users that their code uses customer data as expected? Furthermore, what can we do to stop developers from modifying their code to change how customer data is used? In this talk we will be covering the current problems and how confidential computing can solve them. We will also discuss why you should care about privacy-first services for serverless functions. As well as the value of what code integrity, data integrity and data privacy can do for you and your users.

'abstract': Are your websites accessible to all users? Are all the users able to interact with your application as intended regardless of their disabilities? Accessibility often remains an afterthought, even today. I'm here to share how we can change that. In this talk, we will explore best practices for building user interactions for websites that are accessible and user-friendly for our users. Using semantic HTML and ARIA attributes, we will cover strategies for interaction from a simple button to navigation, to different form elements and custom components. After this session, the audience will understand how users can use websites in different ways. They will learn different ways to test a scenario and see practical code solutions on how to make the interactions accessible.

'abstract': Are your websites accessible to all users? Are all the users able to interact with your application as intended regardless of their disabilities? Accessibility often remains an afterthought, even today. I'm here to share how we can change that. In this talk, we will explore best practices for building user interactions for websites that are accessible and user-friendly for our users. Using semantic HTML and ARIA attributes, we will cover strategies for interaction from a simple button to navigation, to different form elements and custom components. After this session, the audience will understand how users can use websites in different ways. They will learn different ways to test a scenario and see practical code solutions on how to make the interactions accessible.

'title': Welcome and Opening // Keynote: (Ab)User Experience: How the Dark Side of Product and Security Can Be Used for (Ab)User Stories, (Mis)Use Cases and Threat Modelling
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2023

'abstract': We start with a welcome and conference introduction, followed by Jeff Watkins and Lianne Potters keynote: Security can often feel like an unapproachable and mysterious part of an organisation – the department of work prevention, the department of 'nope.' But it doesn’t have to be that way. In this talk, we will look at the unintended users of a product, the 'threat agents'. By engaging the security team in the product development process, we can model the dark side of use cases and user stories through threat modelling techniques. This can help demystify impenetrable security NFRs through concrete examples of how these threat agents may try to misuse your shiny new digital product. Who will benefit from this talk? Those building products/apps exposed to the web; people who want to build awareness of possible attack vector use cases (i.e. how might you be attacked); and people who need to write that down as a set of requirements to help build a DevSecOps approach in projects.

'title': Making Interactions Accessible to All Users

'abstract': Are your websites accessible to all users? Are all the users able to interact with your application as intended regardless of their disabilities? Accessibility often remains an afterthought, even today. I'm here to share how we can change that. In this talk, we will explore best practices for building user interactions for websites that are accessible and user-friendly for our users. Using semantic HTML and ARIA attributes, we will cover strategies for interaction from a simple button to navigation, to different form elements and custom components. After this session, the audience will understand how users can use websites in different ways. They will learn different ways to test a scenario and see practical code solutions on how to make the interactions accessible.

'title': AI-powered learning recommendation system: a map and match approach
'parentName': ML Con Berlin 2022
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2022-11-29T15:45:00.000Z'
'abstract': Among the challenges faced by Human Resources (HR) professionals is the ability to match learning programs to career paths or to individual employees. At the core of this obstacle is the difference between the terms used to describe a training course and those used in the HR systems to describe jobs and career paths. Simply put, no standard terminology is used, either by the employees in the corporate system or by the learning industry professionals. To alleviate this problem, we have created a mapping & matching framework which allows to automatically connect learning with the other areas of corporate talent management. Our solution relies on a standardized database of 3,000 occupations and 13,000 skills. Mapping algorithms are built (i) to identify the occupations which best correspond to a user’s job title (present or desired) and (ii) to identify the skills referred to in a course description. Matching algorithms take the mapping results to estimate the similarity between every single course and user’s profile and provide the top courses that best match to a given user’s profile. The level of accuracy achievable at each step and their variation with some of the properties of the input parameters will be discussed.

'title': The Observability Reset: 4 Foundational Principles for O11y That Scales
'parentName': DevOpsCon New York 2025
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2025-09-30T08:15:00.000Z'
'abstract': Let’s face it, collecting metrics, logs, and traces isn’t enough anymore. Most o11y stacks today are drowning in telemetry, buried in cost overruns, and spread so thin across tools that they’ve become more noise than signal. The classic SaaS-based model is cracking. This talk lays out 4 foundational principles for building a sustainable observability posture that scale with infra and budget: - Bring Your Own Cloud (BYOC): SaaS o11y is financially unsustainable at scale. - Consolidate or Bust: DevEx suffers when visibility is fragmented- consolidation isn’t a luxury - it’s a requirement. - Standardize Everything: Open protocols, pluggable pipelines, and vendor-neutral APIs are the only way forward, or your o11y is a ticking liability. - Self-Reliance: You can’t rely on app-level instrumentation forever - eBPF enables scalable o11y without complexity This session pulls from real-world deployments and lessons learned helping engineering teams scale visibility without compromise.

'parentName': DevOpsCon San Diego 2025

'abstract': In the dynamic landscape of DevOps, minimizing downtime is critical. In a perfect world, applications never fail, but the reality is that outages are inevitable. It remains imperative for IT departments to reduce both the frequency and duration of these disruptions. Despite the clear advantages, many organizations are reluctant to embrace automation due to entrenched manual processes and a lack of resources. In this session, we’ll explore how automation—when combined with real-time observability — can proactively prevent outages and accelerate recovery when incidents do occur. We’ll cover best practices and common challenges in building automation strategies that are both scalable and sustainable. Attendees will leave with actionable insights into how observability-driven automation can improve operational resilience and drive continuous improvement across the software delivery lifecycle.

'title': From GPU Burn‑Rate to Budget‑Friendly: Real‑World Hacks for SFTing Huge LLMs
'parentName': MLcon New York 2025

'abstract': Supervised fine‑tuning (SFT) is still the gold‑standard for aligning large language models to niche domains, yet training bills can dwarf the project budget. This talk walks through the production SFT pipeline we built for LLM (7B → 470 B parameters) and shows how we cut per‑run cost by 42% while shortening wall‑clock time by 28%—all without model‑quality regressions. Attendees will see how we combined parameter‑efficient tricks (LoRA → QLoRA), 3‑D parallelism, FlashAttention‑3, mixed‑precision FP8, and AWS Trainium 2 clusters to squeeze every last TFLOP‑second. We’ll share concrete metrics, CLI snippets, and the open‑sourced orchestration package that glues it together. Expect a brutally honest discussion of what broke, how we fixed it, and where the next 10% of savings will come from

'abstract': 9 von 10 Webanwendungen haben Sicherheitslücken – und das schon seit Jahren. Es vergeht kaum eine Woche, ohne dass ein großer Sicherheitsvorfall bekannt wird. Mit weiter zunehmender Digitalisierung werden sowohl die Anzahl als auch der Schweregrad der erfolgreichen Angriffe steigen. Das muss besser werden! Aus diesem Grund werfen wir einen Blick auf den aktuellen Status Quo der Web Application Security. Welche Informationen und Tools rund um die Web-Sicherheit bietet das Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) dieses Jahr? Macht KI Anwendungen sicherer oder sind KI-Anwendungen unsicher? 'title': Wearable, Shareable... Unbearable?
'parentName': IPC Berlin 2024
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2024-05-30T15:00:00.000Z'
'abstract': In a world of 5G (no conspiracy theories please!) smartphones, smart TVs and smart homes, we're inviting more tech into our lives than ever. We're sleepwalking into a future nobody asked for, but maybe many fear. How always-on Microphones, Cameras and AI are creating a 'digital panopticon' none of us probably want or need, unless you're Amazon. Should we become 'digital preppers'? Is the privacy and security risk so high, what are the stakes? This is an anthro-technologist view on how dumb an idea the smart revolution is and how we've eroded our social contracts in favour of big tech.

'title': Unlocking the DevOps Secret: The Surprising Power of Psychological Safety
'parentName': DevOpsCon Berlin 2024
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2024-06-17T07:45:00.000Z'
'abstract': In the high-pressure world of DevOps, where speed, innovation, and reliability are paramount, one often overlooked factor can be the game-changer your team needs. Join us for a thought-provoking journey into the uncharted territory of the impact of psychological safety on DevOps. In this captivating conference talk, we will delve deep into the unexplored realm of psychological safety and how it can revolutionize your DevOps practices. Discover the untold stories of teams that thrived by fostering a culture of trust and openness, and learn how this secret weapon can lead to higher productivity, faster releases, and better collaboration. Get ready to be inspired, as we unveil the hidden forces that drive top-performing DevOps teams and reveal practical strategies to nurture psychological safety within your own organization. Don't miss this opportunity to gain a competitive edge and become a DevOps trailblazer! Join us and embark on a journey of transformation that will leave you wondering how you ever operated without it.

'title': Designing a Serverless App
'parentName': Serverless Architecture Conference London 2024
'language': 'EN'
'date': '2024-04-09T14:00:00.000Z'
'abstract': Recently, concerns over the cost, complexity, and maintainability of serverless solutions seem to be growing. The ever-increasing number of available services and a growing ecosystem can further increase the confusion or perceived risk of going serverless. This talk will build on 7 years of experience building and maintaining serverless solutions to walk through the ground-up design of a brand-new serverless application. We’ll discuss common questions and concerns including data architecture, security, cost, and maintainability. The solution will be shown using a combination of system diagrams, as well as platform and code examples in Firebase and Google Cloud.
